section.title: Uniform Asymptotic Expansions for Large Order

para.sentence: Define \zeta=\zeta(z) to be the solution of the differential equation \left(\frac{\mathrm{d}\zeta}{\mathrm{d}z}\right)^{2}=\frac{1-z^{2}}{\zeta z^{2}} that is infinitely differentiable on the interval 0<z<\infty , including z=1.

Then \frac{2}{3}\zeta^{\frac{3}{2}}=\int_{z}^{1}\frac{\sqrt{1-t^{2}}}{t}\mathrm{d}t =\ln\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{1-z^{2}}}{z}\right)-\sqrt{1-z^{2}}, if 0<z\leq 1, \frac{2}{3}(-\zeta)^{\frac{3}{2}}=\int_{1}^{z}\frac{\sqrt{t^{2}-1}}{t}\mathrm{ d}t=\sqrt{z^{2}-1}-\operatorname{arcsec}z, if 1\leq z<\infty, all functions taking their principal values, with \zeta=\infty,0,-\infty , corresponding to z=0,1,\infty , respectively.
uniformly for z \in(0,\infty) in all cases, where \mathrm{Ai} and \mathrm{Bi} are the Airy functions (§9.2).

In the following formulas for the coefficients A_{k}(\zeta) , B_{k}(\zeta) , C_{k}(\zeta) , and D_{k}(\zeta) , u_{k} , v_{k} are the constants defined in § 9.7(i), and U_{k}(p) , V_{k}(p) are the polynomials in p of degree 3k defined in §10.41(ii).
In formulas (10.20.10)–(10.20.13)replace
Note: Another way of arranging the above formulas for the coefficients A_{k}(\zeta),B_{k}(\zeta),C_{k}(\zeta) , and D_{k}(\zeta) would be by analogy with (12.10.42) and (12.10.46).
In this way there is less usage of many-valued functions.
Each of the coefficients A_{k}(\zeta) , B_{k}(\zeta) , C_{k}(\zeta) , and D_{k}(\zeta) , k=0,1,2,\ldots , is real and infinitely differentiable on the interval -\infty<\zeta<\infty.
For (10.20.14) and further information on the coefficients see Temme (1997).
For numerical tables of \zeta=\zeta(z) , (4\zeta/(1-z^{2}))^{\frac{1}{4}} and A_{k}(\zeta) , B_{k}(\zeta) , C_{k}(\zeta) , and D_{k}(\zeta) seeOlver (1962, pp. 28–42).

subsection.title: Complex Variables

para.sentence: The function \zeta=\zeta(z) given by (10.20.2) and (10.20.3) can be continued analytically to the z -plane cut along the negative real axis.
Corresponding points of the mapping are shown in Figures 10.20.1 and 10.20.2.

The equations of the curved boundaries D_{1}E_{1} and D_{2}E_{2} in the \zeta -plane are given parametrically by \zeta=(\tfrac{3}{2})^{\frac{2}{3}}(\tau\mp i\pi)^{\frac{2}{3}}, if 0\leq\tau<\infty, respectively.
The curves BP_{1}E_{1} and BP_{2}E_{2} in the z -plane are the inverse maps of the line segments \zeta=e^{\mp i\pi/3}\tau, if 0\leq\tau\leq(\tfrac{3}{2}\pi)^{\frac{2}{3}}, respectively.

They are given parametrically by z=\pm(\tau\coth\tau-\tau^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}}\pm\mathrm{i}(\tau^{2}-\tau\tanh \tau)^{\frac{1}{2}}, if 0\leq\tau\leq\tau_{0}, where \tau_{0}=1.19968\ldot s is the positive root of the equation \tau=\coth\tau.
The points P_{1},P_{2} where these curves intersect the imaginary axis are \pm ic , where c=(\tau_{0}^{2}-1)^{\frac{1}{2}}=0.66274\ldots.
The eye-shaped closed domain in the uncut z -plane that is bounded by BP_{1}E_{1} and BP_{2}E_{2} is denoted by \mathbf{K} ; see Figure10.20.3.

subsection.sentence: Figure 10.20.1: z -plane. P_{1} and P_{2} are the points \pm ic . c=0.66274\ldots .
Figure 10.20.2: \zeta -plane. E_{1} and E_{2} are the points e^{\mp\pi i/3}(3\pi/2)^{2/3}.

para.sentence: As \nu\to\infty through positive real values the expansions (10.20.4)–(10.20.9)apply uniformly for |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi-\delta , the coefficients A_{k}(\zeta) , B_{k}(\zeta) , C_{k}(\zeta) , and D_{k}(\zeta) , being the analytic continuations of the functions defined in §10.20(i) when \zeta is real.
For proofs of the above results and for error bounds and extensions of the regions of validity see Olver (1997b, pp. 419–425).
For extensions to complex \nu see Olver (1954).
For resurgence properties of the coefficients (§2.7(ii)) see Howls and Olde Daalhuis (1999).
For further results see Dunster (2001a), Wang and Wong (2002), and Paris (2004).
For asymptotic properties of the expansions (10.20.4)–(10.20.6) with respect to large values of z see §10.41(v).
